bestBHT.bht: I pray that they should remain in the world to do God's work, but be kept from the evil one. This prayer seeks their sanctification through God's truth, acknowledging the need for divine assistance in keeping believers out of the hands of the evil one. By staying in the world, they can testify and spread the gospel. The prayer asks for protection from all evil in the world, ensuring their safety amidst trials and empowering them to resist the dominion of sin.

Henry Alford: I pray not from the evil, as A.V.; but from the evil one.
Said mostly for their sakes, for whom it was necessary that they should abide yet in the flesh, to do God’s work.
To be sanctified by God’s truth.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I pray not that thou shouldest take them out of the world—for that, though it would secure their own safety, would leave the world unblessed by their testimony.
But . . . keep them from the evil—all evil in and of the world.
Albert Barnes: It would be easy for God to remove his people at once to heaven, but it is better for them to remain, and show the power of religion in supporting the soul in the midst of trial, and to spread his gospel among men.
Shouldest keep them from the evil - This may mean either from the evil one that is, the devil, or from evil in general that is, from apostasy, from sinking in temptation.
Preserve them from that evil, or give them such grace that they may endure all trials and be sustained amid them.
Marvin Vincent: From the evil [του πονηρου] . Or, the evil one. This rendering is according to John's usage. See 1 John 2:13, 1 John 2:14; 1 John 3:12; 1 John 5:18, 1 John 5:19; and compare John 12:31; John 14:30; John 16:11. From [εκ] , literally, out of, means out of the hands of.
John Calvin: He shows in what the safety of believers (121) consists; not that they are free from every annoyance, and live in luxury and at their ease, but that, in the midst of dangers, they continue to be safe through the assistance of God.

He promises to his disciples the grace of the Father; not to relieve them from all anxiety and toil, but to furnish them with invincible strength against their enemies, and not to suffer them to be overwhelmed by the heavy burden of contests which they will have to endure.

If, therefore, we wish to be kept according to the rule which Christ has laid down, we must not desire exemption from evils, or pray to God to convey us immediately into a state of blessed rest, but must rest satisfied with the certain assurance of victory, and, in the meantime, resist courageously all the evils.
Philip Schaff: The expression ‘to be kept out of the evil one’ may surprise the reader until he remembers that in 1 John 5:19-20 the Apostle really speaks of the world as lying in the evil one.
The teaching of this Gospel and of the whole New Testament is that there are two spheres in which man may live, that of the world and its prince, and that of ‘Jesus Christ.’
Our prayer ought to be, not that we may be kept ‘from’ the one, but that we may be kept ‘out of’ the one and ‘in’ the other.
Archibald T. Robertson: Shouldest take (αρηις). First aorist active subjunctive of αιρω (liquid verb).
From the evil one (εκ του πονηρου). Ablative case with εκ, but can mean the evil man, Satan, or the evil deed.
But in 1 John 5:18 ο πονηρος is masculine (the evil one).
John Gill: but that thou shouldest keep them from the evil; either of sin, which is an evil and bitter thing, being committed against a good God, and a righteous law, and brings ruin and destruction upon men
from this the apostles were kept, and all the saints are; not from indwelling sin, nor from the commission of sin, but from the dominion of it

Christ's praying for this, after this manner, shows that evil is very abhorrent, pernicious and powerful; the danger saints are in by it; their incapacity to keep themselves from it; and that the Lord alone is the keeper of his people
John Wesley: That thou wouldest take them out of the world — Not yet: but that thou wouldest keep them from the evil one - Who reigns therein.

bhtAttempts.bht: I pray that you should not take them out of the world, but keep them from the evil one. This prayer, spoken for the sake of those who must stay in the world to fulfill God's work, asks for their sanctification through God's truth. By remaining in the world, they can bear witness to the power of religion and spread the gospel. This prayer seeks not only their safety, but also the protection from all evil in the world. It acknowledges the need for divine assistance in keeping believers out of the hands of the evil one, ensuring their victory over sin and resistance against the heavy burdens they will face.

I pray that you should not take them out of the world, but keep them from the evil one. This prayer, for those who must remain in the world, seeks their sanctification through God's truth. By staying, they demonstrate the power of religion amidst trials and spread the gospel. It asks for protection from all evil, acknowledging the need for divine assistance to keep believers out of the hands of the evil one and ensuring their victory over sin and burdens.

The prayer seeks protection from all evil, acknowledging the need for divine assistance to keep believers out of the hands of the evil one and secure their victory over sin and burdens.
